text: Family Member: I wanted, I want your input, uh but we couldn’t just give him that - because he is all at that level of three injections of testosterone, he’s a perfect candidate just for that immune thing just to see? (Beeping) Doctor: Well, the immune thing is normally I, I don’t. We’re not allowed to give anything unless it’s in a disease where it’s been approved- Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: because the cost is so very high, the hospital won’t let us do anything. So normally what we have to do is go through the insurance company, tell them what we wanted to do, they deny it, you write letters. So it’s not something that I can just do it tomorrow. Family Member: So you can’t ask-? Doctor: Now you, you know, who have, you’re a person of means, that maybe you could just pay for it, but I haven’t really, I don’t know what the avenue is to do that. (Laughs) Family Member: Well- Patient: Give, give that some thought, too. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Like maybe it’s, if you think it is worthwhile doing since I’m already trying with the testosterone to do it, uh. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You can follow a number of avenues. Doctor: I could ask the pharmacist if there’s a way that, you know, if the patient could actually just pay for it themselves and just get it.

text: Patient: Yes. Doctor: Which we think is probably prostate cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And uh we had discussed a lot of options around that that we were gonna talk a little bit more about today is this concept of giving a special type of radiation therapy which called stereotactic radiotherapy to that lymph node. Possibly to other lymph nodes as well. This is a very focused beam of ray therapy that also goes by many other names included the name CyberKnife even though it’s not a true knife. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But uh it’s kind of precise as a knife which is where it got the name. It’s also called SBRT, stereotactic body radiotherapy. With SBRT or Cyber Knife or stereotactic radiotherapy it’s always the same thing. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So we have um two or three uh radiation oncologists here that specialize in that type of therapy for prostate cancer patients. And the other things that are I want to discuss um with you today is a clinical trial – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - where we’re using that type of therapy but instead of not using it and not following um patients and getting data from them, we want learn something from their experience. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: And also want to compare the outcomes of patients who get the stereotactic radiotherapy immediately versus those that are observed for a period of time and then we’ll get the stereotactic radiotherapy a little bit later. PAT; Okay. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - is open for discussion is to treat this as if it was a prostate cancer and see if it goes away. Patient: Okay, so - Doctor: And if it does, and in retrospect, because if we give you a hormone therapy, for example and it’s a gist, it will not increase sized at all. Patient: Correct. Doctor: If it’s a hormone therapy and it’s prostate cancer, you know it’s gonna disappear or decrease by ninety percent within the first few months. Patient: Okay, would that be your recommendation, to do more hormonal? Doctor: Well, I was gonna, I was gonna talk to you about that. Um… Patient: Right. Doctor: I think it it probably - some type of hormone therapy is probably gonna be in your near future. It might not be the immediate future, but I think sooner rather than later given that we’ve tried this sort of outside-the-box non-hormonal type of therapy and it hasn’t really you know worked as well as we had hoped, the next step I think given that the PSA is rising and given that this lymph node is increasing, I do happen to believe it’s prostate cancer would lead me to the conclusion that hormone therapy is probably the next best thing to do. Patient: Now with hormonal therapy, um it is not a cure. It’s just a uh–. Doctor: That’s correct… It’s - Patient: Okay, so it’s not a cure. The only thing it would be doing is slowing down the progress of the, it would slow down the -

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: It looks like there’s more now. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I, I don’t think we could do that radiation. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, just because of the number of them. Patient: Right. Doctor: We do, speaking of trials, we do have a trial coming up. It’s not open yet. But it’s probably going to be a trial after, uh, uh, actually, let me, let me take a step back. The other trial I didn’t tell you. We do have one other trial, uh, that involves, uh, a combination of two things. Uh, one is called, radium. And radium is a radioactive element that looks like calcium. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the idea is we can trick the cancer, because prostate cancer is making, stimulating the bone to make new bone. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we give this radium that looks like calcium, so he gets put in there also, and can give radiation kind of focally. So where there’s spots on the bone, it gives radiation, but it doesn’t radiate the liver or the lung. Patient: Right. Right.

text: Patient: To go to Cornell. Doctor: Cornell or UCLA, so, yeah. Patient: Well, I guess I would ask you, if possible, to check out both avenues. I’d want to see which one. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I mean my interest, our interest, is just to stop this stuff from growing. It seems to be growing at a consistent pace. I don’t know if it’s slow, fast, or whatever, but it’s not stopping. And do you think that this, this sort of, from what you know from this, from the, you know PSMA, that would have a real uh opportunity to stop the growth? Doctor: Yeah. I think from the data they published, it actually looks really good, uh, and- Patient: If it’s so good, why don’t they, why does it take so long in the U.S. then to get these? Doctor: So, in Germany, and Australia, I know they’re also doing it in Australia. I know it’s a little farther for you- Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Uh in Germany they have a law that if the doctor thinks something is beneficial it doesn’t have to be you know like you know in America, FDA approved. So the FDA, the bar is show me it makes people live longer. It’s a pretty high bar. Because that requires a lot of patients, a lot time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but at the end of the day, you feel really confident that what I’m giving you could help.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
